Study_Loc:
Wrangell St. Elias National Park and Pre-
serve in southcentral Alaska
caribou data?: analysis of epidermal fragments of plants in 20 fecal samples, each sample has 10-15 pellet groups
dates of sampling: In 1994; 1 sample pre parturition period, 7 peak parturition period (mid-may), 4 post parturition period (June?). In 1995; 4 at high and 4 at low elevations.
unit: Density values for fragments in feces were calculated from 100 microscope views for identi- fication to forage class, and from 150 micro- scope views for each composite of groups iden- tified to species
spatial: High and low elevata diet data available
Notes: Looked at females with claves pre-parturition and post parturition Data reported here is post parturition but available for pre and peak partition. Also avaialble for high and low elevation

caribou data?: analysis of rumen contents of 72 samples
dates of sampling: Between 2000-2002, 26 rumen samples in Oct (early winter)
annual: Data available in supplement for 3 years
Notes: Reported here are the cumulative of plants identified. 60% of plant fragments could be ID'd

caribou data?: Observation of foraging and analysis of 32 fecal samples, each sample had 25 pellets from 25 different pellet groups
dates of sampling: 190 days through the year for observation, Female fecal samples: 8 in spring 26 May-25 June,
unit: Average precentages of discerened plant fragments in fecal samples collected from adult female caribou
Notes: These are the values from just adult females from only fecal analyese. The study also conducted a combined effort of fecal, field observation, and forage digestiabiliies not reported here for adult femals, and had 2 data points for calves and 3 data points for bulls

caribou data?: Estimates of plant growth form found in digestibility corrected diets using microhistological analysis. Each sample had 5-10 fecal pellets from 8-10 pellet groups.
dates of sampling: June, July, Fall (Sept-Oct), Winter (Nov.-March) and Spring (April-May).
sample_size: composite of 5Ð 10 fecal pellets from 8Ð10 distinct pellet groups.
unit: Mean (±SE) percentage of plant growth form found in digestibility corrected seasonal diets
Notes: The acutal paper discusses isotope data, but reports microhistological data from a 2008 thesis that is not published. The data reported here are from that thesis

caribou data?: histological analysis of fecal samples, each of the 14 samples had 1 pellet from 3-10 pellet groups

sample_size: 14 fecal samples
unit: mean ± SE diet composition of caribou and bison based on identification of discernible plant fragments

caribou data?: A composite sample of feces was created for each foraging site to estimate the proportion of plants within forage groups in the diet. Composite samples (Table 1) were created by randomly selecting 5Ð10 pellets from each fecal sample collected at a site
sample_size: n of sites = 4 (uknown n of samples)
unit: Composition (percent of diet) and corrected by the desnity of plant framents in feces for apparent digestibality (boertje 1990_
Notes: Authors State: Characteristics of diet and terrain did not differ by ecotype or herd

Notes on Study_loc: Northing given, longitued estimated from map
caribou data?: Analysis of plant fragments in fecal sample
unit: Diet composition (mean ± SE %) of caribou in northwest Alaska derived from microhistology of feces collected in 2012 that were corrected for digestibility (sensu Gustine et al., 2011).
spatial: Diets of GMH caribou had more lichen than the arctic caribou. The amount of lichen in the diet of caribou at a given location declined with increasing latitude
Notes: pregnant caribou had less lichen (70.1%; 95% CI 66.5Ð 73.6%) in the diet than non-pregnant caribou (75.8%; 95% CI 70.1Ð81.6%) and males (75.9%; 95% CI 72.8Ð79.0%; F2, 206 = 3.49, P = 0.03; Table 1).
